abstract.text: Returns a Core Graphics image object that captures the drawing of the image.

inlineContent.text: On input, the proposed destination rectangle for drawing the image. If
, it defaults to the smallest pixel-integral rectangle containing
. The
is in user space in the reference context.
On output, the
may have been altered. This is because a
is necessarily pixel-integral, while an
is not. In order to produce a
for rect
without distortion or double-antialiasing, we may have to produce a 5x5
, and also inflate the
. Drawing the
in the out-value
is the same as drawing the
in the in-value of proposed rect.
A graphics context. Can be
An optional dictionary of hints that provide more context for selecting or generating the image. See
for a summary of the possible key-value pairs.
A
. This may be an existing
if one is available. If not, a new
is created.
An
is potentially resolution independent, and may have representations that allow it to draw well in many contexts. A
is more like a single pixel-based representation. This method produces a snapshot of how the
would draw if it was asked to draw in the proposed rectangle in the graphics context.
All input parameters are optional. They provide hints for how to choose among existing
objects, or how to create one if there isn’t already a
available. The parameters are only hints.
This method is intended as an override point for image representation subclasses that naturally have a
available. For example,
overrides it to return the
that naturally backs the representation. You don’t need to override the method except possibly for performance, though. The
-level implementation will produce a
by making a buffer and calling
. That’s likely to be the best possible implementation for reps that aren’t naturally
-backed. The
method remains the only method of
that a subclasser really needs to override.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
An object that renders an image from bitmap data.
An object that represents a graphics context.
A high-level interface for manipulating image data.
A semiabstract superclass that provides subclasses that you use to draw an image from a particular type of source data.
Constants for the keys to include in a hints dictionary when drawing the image.
Returns a Core Graphics image object that captures the drawing of the image.
Implemented by subclasses to draw the image in the current coordinate system.
A bitmap image or image mask.
A bitmap image or image mask.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
